name: nytimes
text: Friends, classmates and others who have known Joe Biden for decades describe a man keen on bringing a 1950s sensibi… https://t.co/ByRLskUFDd

name: nytimes
text: As a college and law school student in the tumultuous 1960s, Joe Biden seemed unmoved by the fury over Civil Rights and the Vietnam War displayed by many of his peers. “Other people marched,” Biden said in 1987. “I ran for office.” https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt https://t.co/SjqH6ZyBkN

name: nytimes
text: Those who knew Joe Biden in college describe a young man on campus wearing a tasteful button-down and chinos, honing his self-styled political brand: polished but unpretentious, with institutionalist instincts before he was part of any institutions. https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt https://t.co/a8dKWhBOSU

name: nytimes
text: Joe Biden’s exposure to the main issues of the 1960s — Civil Rights and the Vietnam War — came off-campus. He has long cited his experience as a lifeguard at a pool in a largely Black part of town as instrumental in his understanding of the racial divide. https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt https://t.co/gaaxGRlqpm

name: nytimes
text: After law school, Joe Biden seemed focused on establishing a mainstream political career for himself, friends say. It was evident in how he dressed, the jobs he pursued and even in his personal choices. He named his dogs Governor and Senator. https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt https://t.co/3ImK8fIZtR

name: nytimes
text: It can be hard now to imagine Joe Biden as a young man — or, at least, a younger man than he was when he first reached Washington, as a 30-year-old senator shattered by the car crash that killed his first wife, Neilia, and their baby daughter. https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt https://t.co/1uYh6Jxq4b

name: nytimes
text: Read more about the young Joe Biden by @mattfleg and @katieglueck in the latest Long Run article, part of a series that explores the lives and careers of the 2020 presidential candidates. https://t.co/2DCddqaPNt

name: nytimes
text: Two words — “white supremacy” — have poured into America’s rhetorical bloodstream, with some saying old descriptions like “racism” and “bigotry” are too tame for this raw moment. But the use of the term has touched off an intense debate. https://t.co/SYTn6GDCiP

name: nytimes
text: The phrase “white supremacy” used to refer to the KKK and neo-Nazis. Now its use has exploded to refer to the NFL, museums and supermarket products. Yet its use is highly contentious. https://t.co/In0RHXZHNc https://t.co/puH2FmlnVG
